10.17.17  6:02 pm   What's the point in using double flats and double sharps when you can just write the note a whole step higher? This has perplexed me for quite a while.

     let's say you are in Gb with a Gb key signature. and you wanna borrow a little minor. it might be easier, to drop a "bb" on the B, rather than trying to put Ab and Anatural next to each other in the scale. if you use Bbb then the scale will flow normally on the page without having to keep flipping the A flat-natural back and forth. but don't take my word for it, try it yourself and see which is more convenient

10.17.17  5:56 pm   Your skull will become concave due to the vacuum created by the constant outflow of your creativity.

     that's not true

     Will you:

a) Stuff you head with cotton balls, to return your skull to its original shape (and how will you get them in there)?

b) Stop being creative to break the vacuum, then go to dent wizard to have them pull out the concave surface of your skull (and will your insurance cover this)?

c) Avoid getting a concave skull by becoming a non-creative "normie" (Bonus points: Will your new career be an account, a politician, or a Hollywood director)?

d) Continue to be creative until, through the force of aforementioned vacuum, you turn yourself inside out (at which point it may become even harder to find a date, and random carnivores will start to chew on you)? Why or why not?

     i always make them as good as i can. longer ones take longer to make, so i am currently focusing on videos of a medium size

10.17.17  2:09 pm   I'm new to making music, I use lmms to learn composing some tune that comes to my mind. Sometimes in the middle of the day I get a tune but I won't be able to remember it when I get in front of the computer. Can you please tell me how I could write the tune down, so I can refer to it later. What symbols should I use to write the tune? Thank you.

     nowadays the best way to write down something musical is to make a quick recording of yourself singing it, or playing it

10.17.17  2:04 pm   Do you ever run out of ideas?

     no

10.17.17  1:38 pm   Are pumpkins scary enough for Halloween?

     i guess they will have to be

10.17.17  1:15 pm   10.16.17  12:57 pm I think you said that you mostly use a voice memo thing for getting ideas down when they come to you... do you usually just sing the main melody? Are you able to come up with chords/harmony in your head, and if so, how would you record that? What about drum parts/bass line? 

     melody, lyric, then just explain anything else that seems important or not obvious. chords for a melody are often obvious. like when you draw a duck's head, it's pretty much assumed that you're gonna have a duck's body there too. another important thing is to count it off, because a melody sung out of thin air can be ambiguous about where the top of the bar is. so i might count off, might orient the key in case it's not clear, might clarify what the chords are if necessary, and for the groove i might quickly sing something or might compare it to another song's groove, for reference. if i have a keyboard available i might play/sing a quick demo. i often over explain, especially in terms of count-off, because new ideas can disappear easily and you might not know how the time is oriented so i try to be as clear as possible

10.16.17  9:04 pm   Question for Bill Wurtz on 10.1.17 4:23 pm : "define random."

Bill says chosen without reason blah blah preferably by computer to eliminate accidental reasoning

I feel the particular response to be inadequate due to some research

"One thing that traditional computer systems aren't good at is coin flipping," says Steve Ward, Professor of Computer Science and Engineering at MIT's Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory. "They're deterministic, which means that if you ask the same question you'll get the same answer every time. In fact, such machines are specifically and carefully programmed to eliminate randomness in results. They do this by following rules and relying on algorithms when they compute."

You can program a machine to generate what can be called "random" numbers, but the machine is always at the mercy of its programming. "On a completely det erminist ic machine you can't generate anything you could really call a random sequence of numbers," says Ward, "because the machine is following the same algorithm to generate them. Typically, that means it starts with a common 'seed' number and then follows a pattern." The results may be sufficiently complex to make the pattern difficult to identify, but because it is ruled by a carefully defined and consistently repeated algorithm, the numbers it produces are not truly random. "They are what we call 'pseudo-random' numbers," Ward says.

- MIT School of Engineering

How do you feel about this? Will you stay with your stance of preferring computers to eliminate accidental reasoning or have you been influenced to believe that the machine can never trump human creativity 

     if you just take a number value associated with the current time, on a very small scale, and convert it to mod7 for example, (if you are looking for a number from 1 to 7) you will easily get random choices that no human user could ever manipulate. but furthermore, there are even some more advanced techniques happening on random.org which enables it to easily give me random sequences of numbers which are more than good enough for anything i could possibly need random numbers for
